text: These are the words of the Teacher, King David’s son, who ruled in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Everything is meaningless,” says the Teacher, “completely meaningless!”
speaker: Narrator

text: What do people get for all their hard work under the sun?
speaker: Narrator

text: Generations come and generations go, but the earth never changes.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun rises and the sun sets, then hurries around to rise again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wind blows south, and then turns north. Around and around it goes, blowing in circles.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rivers run into the sea, but the sea is never full. Then the water returns again to the rivers and flows out again to the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything is wearisome beyond description. No matter how much we see, we are never satisfied. No matter how much we hear, we are not content.
speaker: Narrator

text: History merely repeats itself. It has all been done before. Nothing under the sun is truly new.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometimes people say, “Here is something new!” But actually it is old; nothing is ever truly new.
speaker: Narrator

text: We don’t remember what happened in the past, and in future generations, no one will remember what we are doing now.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, the Teacher, was king of Israel, and I lived in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: I devoted myself to search for understanding and to explore by wisdom everything being done under heaven. I soon discovered that God has dealt a tragic existence to the human race.
speaker: Narrator

text: I observed everything going on under the sun, and really, it is all meaningless—like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is wrong cannot be made right.
    What is missing cannot be recovered.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to myself, “Look, I am wiser than any of the kings who ruled in Jerusalem before me. I have greater wisdom and knowledge than any of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I set out to learn everything from wisdom to madness and folly. But I learned firsthand that pursuing all this is like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The greater my wisdom, the greater my grief.
    To increase knowledge only increases sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to myself, “Come on, let’s try pleasure. Let’s look for the ‘good things’ in life.” But I found that this, too, was meaningless.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I said, “Laughter is silly. What good does it do to seek pleasure?”
speaker: Narrator

text: After much thought, I decided to cheer myself with wine. And while still seeking wisdom, I clutched at foolishness. In this way, I tried to experience the only happiness most people find during their brief life in this world.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also tried to find meaning by building huge homes for myself and by planting beautiful vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: I made gardens and parks, filling them with all kinds of fruit trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: I built reservoirs to collect the water to irrigate my many flourishing groves.
speaker: Narrator

text: I bought slaves, both men and women, and others were born into my household. I also owned large herds and flocks, more than any of the kings who had lived in Jerusalem before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I collected great sums of silver and gold, the treasure of many kings and provinces. I hired wonderful singers, both men and women, and had many beautiful concubines. I had everything a man could desire!
speaker: Narrator

text: So I became greater than all who had lived in Jerusalem before me, and my wisdom never failed me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything I wanted, I would take. I denied myself no pleasure. I even found great pleasure in hard work, a reward for all my labors.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as I looked at everything I had worked so hard to accomplish, it was all so meaningless—like chasing the wind. There was nothing really worthwhile anywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I decided to compare wisdom with foolishness and madness (for who can do this better than I, the king?).
speaker: Narrator

text: I thought, “Wisdom is better than foolishness, just as light is better than darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the wise can see where they are going, but fools walk in the dark.” Yet I saw that the wise and the foolish share the same fate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both will die. So I said to myself, “Since I will end up the same as the fool, what’s the value of all my wisdom? This is all so meaningless!”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the wise and the foolish both die. The wise will not be remembered any longer than the fool. In the days to come, both will be forgotten.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I came to hate life because everything done here under the sun is so troubling. Everything is meaningless—like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: I came to hate all my hard work here on earth, for I must leave to others everything I have earned.
speaker: Narrator

text: And who can tell whether my successors will be wise or foolish? Yet they will control everything I have gained by my skill and hard work under the sun. How meaningless!
speaker: Narrator

text: So I gave up in despair, questioning the value of all my hard work in this world.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some people work wisely with knowledge and skill, then must leave the fruit of their efforts to someone who hasn’t worked for it. This, too, is meaningless, a great tragedy.
speaker: Narrator

text: So what do people get in this life for all their hard work and anxiety?
speaker: Narrator

text: Their days of labor are filled with pain and grief; even at night their minds cannot rest. It is all meaningless.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I decided there is nothing better than to enjoy food and drink and to find satisfaction in work. Then I realized that these pleasures are from the hand of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who can eat or enjoy anything apart from him?
speaker: Narrator

text: God gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy to those who please him. But if a sinner becomes wealthy, God takes the wealth away and gives it to those who please him. This, too, is meaningless—like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For everything there is a season,
    a time for every activity under heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A time to be born and a time to die.
    A time to plant and a time to harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A time to kill and a time to heal.
    A time to tear down and a time to build up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A time to cry and a time to laugh.
    A time to grieve and a time to dance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A time to scatter stones and a time to gather stones.
    A time to embrace and a time to turn away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A time to search and a time to quit searching.
    A time to keep and a time to throw away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A time to tear and a time to mend.
    A time to be quiet and a time to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A time to love and a time to hate.
    A time for war and a time for peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What do people really get for all their hard work?
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen the burden God has placed on us all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet God has made everything beautiful for its own time. He has planted eternity in the human heart, but even so, people cannot see the whole scope of God’s work from beginning to end.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I concluded there is nothing better than to be happy and enjoy ourselves as long as we can.
speaker: Narrator

text: And people should eat and drink and enjoy the fruits of their labor, for these are gifts from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I know that whatever God does is final. Nothing can be added to it or taken from it. God’s purpose is that people should fear him.
speaker: Narrator

text: What is happening now has happened before, and what will happen in the future has happened before, because God makes the same things happen over and over again.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also noticed that under the sun there is evil in the courtroom. Yes, even the courts of law are corrupt!
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to myself, “In due season God will judge everyone, both good and bad, for all their deeds.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I also thought about the human condition—how God proves to people that they are like animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: For people and animals share the same fate—both breathe and both must die. So people have no real advantage over the animals. How meaningless!
speaker: Narrator

text: Both go to the same place—they came from dust and they return to dust.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who can prove that the human spirit goes up and the spirit of animals goes down into the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text: So I saw that there is nothing better for people than to be happy in their work. That is our lot in life. And no one can bring us back to see what happens after we die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again, I observed all the oppression that takes place under the sun. I saw the tears of the oppressed, with no one to comfort them. The oppressors have great power, and their victims are helpless.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I concluded that the dead are better off than the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: But most fortunate of all are those who are not yet born. For they have not seen all the evil that is done under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I observed that most people are motivated to success because they envy their neighbors. But this, too, is meaningless—like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Fools fold their idle hands,
    leading them to ruin.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And yet,
“Better to have one handful with quietness
    than two handfuls with hard work
    and chasing the wind.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I observed yet another example of something meaningless under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the case of a man who is all alone, without a child or a brother, yet who works hard to gain as much wealth as he can. But then he asks himself, “Who am I working for? Why am I giving up so much pleasure now?” It is all so meaningless and depressing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two people are better off than one, for they can help each other succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one person falls, the other can reach out and help. But someone who falls alone is in real trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise, two people lying close together can keep each other warm. But how can one be warm alone?
speaker: Narrator

text: A person standing alone can be attacked and defeated, but two can stand back-to-back and conquer. Three are even better, for a triple-braided cord is not easily broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to be a poor but wise youth than an old and foolish king who refuses all advice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Such a youth could rise from poverty and succeed. He might even become king, though he has been in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then everyone rushes to the side of yet another youth who replaces him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Endless crowds stand around him, but then another generation grows up and rejects him, too. So it is all meaningless—like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: As you enter the house of God, keep your ears open and your mouth shut. It is evil to make mindless offerings to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t make rash promises, and don’t be hasty in bringing matters before God. After all, God is in heaven, and you are here on earth. So let your words be few.
speaker: Narrator

text: Too much activity gives you restless dreams; too many words make you a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you make a promise to God, don’t delay in following through, for God takes no pleasure in fools. Keep all the promises you make to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to say nothing than to make a promise and not keep it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t let your mouth make you sin. And don’t defend yourself by telling the Temple messenger that the promise you made was a mistake. That would make God angry, and he might wipe out everything you have achieved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Talk is cheap, like daydreams and other useless activities. Fear God instead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be surprised if you see a poor person being oppressed by the powerful and if justice is being miscarried throughout the land. For every official is under orders from higher up, and matters of justice get lost in red tape and bureaucracy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the king milks the land for his own profit!
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who love money will never have enough. How meaningless to think that wealth brings true happiness!
speaker: Narrator

text: The more you have, the more people come to help you spend it. So what good is wealth—except perhaps to watch it slip through your fingers!
speaker: Narrator

text: People who work hard sleep well, whether they eat little or much. But the rich seldom get a good night’s sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is another serious problem I have seen under the sun. Hoarding riches harms the saver.
speaker: Narrator

text: Money is put into risky investments that turn sour, and everything is lost. In the end, there is nothing left to pass on to one’s children.
speaker: Narrator

text: We all come to the end of our lives as naked and empty-handed as on the day we were born. We can’t take our riches with us.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this, too, is a very serious problem. People leave this world no better off than when they came. All their hard work is for nothing—like working for the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throughout their lives, they live under a cloud—frustrated, discouraged, and angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so, I have noticed one thing, at least, that is good. It is good for people to eat, drink, and enjoy their work under the sun during the short life God has given them, and to accept their lot in life.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it is a good thing to receive wealth from God and the good health to enjoy it. To enjoy your work and accept your lot in life—this is indeed a gift from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: God keeps such people so busy enjoying life that they take no time to brood over the past.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is another serious tragedy I have seen under the sun, and it weighs heavily on humanity.
speaker: Narrator

text: God gives some people great wealth and honor and everything they could ever want, but then he doesn’t give them the chance to enjoy these things. They die, and someone else, even a stranger, ends up enjoying their wealth! This is meaningless—a sickening tragedy.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man might have a hundred children and live to be very old. But if he finds no satisfaction in life and doesn’t even get a decent burial, it would have been better for him to be born dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: His birth would have been meaningless, and he would have ended in darkness. He wouldn’t even have had a name,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he would never have seen the sun or known of its existence. Yet he would have had more peace than in growing up to be an unhappy man.
speaker: Narrator

text: He might live a thousand years twice over but still not find contentment. And since he must die like everyone else—well, what’s the use?
speaker: Narrator

text: All people spend their lives scratching for food, but they never seem to have enough.
speaker: Narrator

text: So are wise people really better off than fools? Do poor people gain anything by being wise and knowing how to act in front of others?
speaker: Narrator

text: Enjoy what you have rather than desiring what you don’t have. Just dreaming about nice things is meaningless—like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything has already been decided. It was known long ago what each person would be. So there’s no use arguing with God about your destiny.
speaker: Narrator

text: The more words you speak, the less they mean. So what good are they?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the few days of our meaningless lives, who knows how our days can best be spent? Our lives are like a shadow. Who can tell what will happen on this earth after we are gone?
speaker: Narrator

text:
A good reputation is more valuable than costly perfume.
    And the day you die is better than the day you are born.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to spend your time at funerals than at parties.
    After all, everyone dies—
    so the living should take this to heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sorrow is better than laughter,
    for sadness has a refining influence on us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise person thinks a lot about death,
    while a fool thinks only about having a good time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be criticized by a wise person
    than to be praised by a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool’s laughter is quickly gone,
    like thorns crackling in a fire.
    This also is meaningless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Extortion turns wise people into fools,
    and bribes corrupt the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Finishing is better than starting.
    Patience is better than pride.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Control your temper,
    for anger labels you a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t long for “the good old days.”
    This is not wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is even better when you have money.
    Both are a benefit as you go through life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom and money can get you almost anything,
    but only wisdom can save your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Accept the way God does things,
    for who can straighten what he has made crooked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Enjoy prosperity while you can,
    but when hard times strike, realize that both come from God.
    Remember that nothing is certain in this life.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen everything in this meaningless life, including the death of good young people and the long life of wicked people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So don’t be too good or too wise! Why destroy yourself?
speaker: Narrator

text: On the other hand, don’t be too wicked either. Don’t be a fool! Why die before your time?
speaker: Narrator

text: Pay attention to these instructions, for anyone who fears God will avoid both extremes.
speaker: Narrator

text: One wise person is stronger than ten leading citizens of a town!
speaker: Narrator

text: Not a single person on earth is always good and never sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t eavesdrop on others—you may hear your servant curse you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you know how often you yourself have cursed others.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have always tried my best to let wisdom guide my thoughts and actions. I said to myself, “I am determined to be wise.” But it didn’t work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom is always distant and difficult to find.
speaker: Narrator

text: I searched everywhere, determined to find wisdom and to understand the reason for things. I was determined to prove to myself that wickedness is stupid and that foolishness is madness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I discovered that a seductive woman is a trap more bitter than death. Her passion is a snare, and her soft hands are chains. Those who are pleasing to God will escape her, but sinners will be caught in her snare.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is my conclusion,” says the Teacher. “I discovered this after looking at the matter from every possible angle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though I have searched repeatedly, I have not found what I was looking for. Only one out of a thousand men is virtuous, but not one woman!
speaker: Narrator

text: But I did find this: God created people to be virtuous, but they have each turned to follow their own downward path.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
How wonderful to be wise,
    to analyze and interpret things.
Wisdom lights up a person’s face,
    softening its harshness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obey the king since you vowed to God that you would.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t try to avoid doing your duty, and don’t stand with those who plot evil, for the king can do whatever he wants.
speaker: Narrator

text: His command is backed by great power. No one can resist or question it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who obey him will not be punished. Those who are wise will find a time and a way to do what is right,
speaker: Narrator

text: for there is a time and a way for everything, even when a person is in trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, how can people avoid what they don’t know is going to happen?
speaker: Narrator

text: None of us can hold back our spirit from departing. None of us has the power to prevent the day of our death. There is no escaping that obligation, that dark battle. And in the face of death, wickedness will certainly not rescue the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have thought deeply about all that goes on here under the sun, where people have the power to hurt each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen wicked people buried with honor. Yet they were the very ones who frequented the Temple and are now praised in the same city where they committed their crimes! This, too, is meaningless.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a crime is not punished quickly, people feel it is safe to do wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: But even though a person sins a hundred times and still lives a long time, I know that those who fear God will be better off.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wicked will not prosper, for they do not fear God. Their days will never grow long like the evening shadows.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is not all that is meaningless in our world. In this life, good people are often treated as though they were wicked, and wicked people are often treated as though they were good. This is so meaningless!
speaker: Narrator

text: So I recommend having fun, because there is nothing better for people in this world than to eat, drink, and enjoy life. That way they will experience some happiness along with all the hard work God gives them under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: In my search for wisdom and in my observation of people’s burdens here on earth, I discovered that there is ceaseless activity, day and night.
speaker: Narrator

text: I realized that no one can discover everything God is doing under the sun. Not even the wisest people discover everything, no matter what they claim.
speaker: Narrator

text: This, too, I carefully explored: Even though the actions of godly and wise people are in God’s hands, no one knows whether God will show them favor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same destiny ultimately awaits everyone, whether righteous or wicked, good or bad, ceremonially clean or unclean, religious or irreligious. Good people receive the same treatment as sinners, and people who make promises to God are treated like people who don’t.
speaker: Narrator

text: It seems so wrong that everyone under the sun suffers the same fate. Already twisted by evil, people choose their own mad course, for they have no hope. There is nothing ahead but death anyway.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is hope only for the living. As they say, “It’s better to be a live dog than a dead lion!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The living at least know they will die, but the dead know nothing. They have no further reward, nor are they remembered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever they did in their lifetime—loving, hating, envying—is all long gone. They no longer play a part in anything here on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: So go ahead. Eat your food with joy, and drink your wine with a happy heart, for God approves of this!
speaker: Narrator

text: Wear fine clothes, with a splash of cologne!
speaker: Narrator

text: Live happily with the woman you love through all the meaningless days of life that God has given you under the sun. The wife God gives you is your reward for all your earthly toil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever you do, do well. For when you go to the grave, there will be no work or planning or knowledge or wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have observed something else under the sun. The fastest runner doesn’t always win the race, and the strongest warrior doesn’t always win the battle. The wise sometimes go hungry, and the skillful are not necessarily wealthy. And those who are educated don’t always lead successful lives. It is all decided by chance, by being in the right place at the right time.
speaker: Narrator

text: People can never predict when hard times might come. Like fish in a net or birds in a trap, people are caught by sudden tragedy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is another bit of wisdom that has impressed me as I have watched the way our world works.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a small town with only a few people, and a great king came with his army and besieged it.
speaker: Narrator

text: A poor, wise man knew how to save the town, and so it was rescued. But afterward no one thought to thank him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So even though wisdom is better than strength, those who are wise will be despised if they are poor. What they say will not be appreciated for long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to hear the quiet words of a wise person
    than the shouts of a foolish king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to have wisdom than weapons of war,
    but one sinner can destroy much that is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As dead flies cause even a bottle of perfume to stink,
    so a little foolishness spoils great wisdom and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise person chooses the right road;
    a fool takes the wrong one.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You can identify fools
    just by the way they walk down the street!
speaker: Narrator

text:
If your boss is angry at you, don’t quit!
    A quiet spirit can overcome even great mistakes.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is another evil I have seen under the sun. Kings and rulers make a grave mistake
speaker: Narrator

text: when they give great authority to foolish people and low positions to people of proven worth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have even seen servants riding horseback like princes—and princes walking like servants!
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you dig a well,
    you might fall in.
When you demolish an old wall,
    you could be bitten by a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you work in a quarry,
    stones might fall and crush you.
When you chop wood,
    there is danger with each stroke of your ax.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Using a dull ax requires great strength,
    so sharpen the blade.
That’s the value of wisdom;
    it helps you succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a snake bites before you charm it,
    what’s the use of being a snake charmer?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise words bring approval,
    but fools are destroyed by their own words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools base their thoughts on foolish assumptions,
    so their conclusions will be wicked madness;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Fools are so exhausted by a little work
    that they can’t even find their way home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What sorrow for the land ruled by a servant,
    the land whose leaders feast in the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Happy is the land whose king is a noble leader
    and whose leaders feast at the proper time
    to gain strength for their work, not to get drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Laziness leads to a sagging roof;
    idleness leads to a leaky house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A party gives laughter,
    wine gives happiness,
    and money gives everything!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never make light of the king, even in your thoughts.
    And don’t make fun of the powerful, even in your own bedroom.
For a little bird might deliver your message
    and tell them what you said.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Send your grain across the seas,
    and in time, profits will flow back to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But divide your investments among many places,
    for you do not know what risks might lie ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When clouds are heavy, the rains come down.
    Whether a tree falls north or south, it stays where it falls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Farmers who wait for perfect weather never plant.
    If they watch every cloud, they never harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as you cannot understand the path of the wind or the mystery of a tiny baby growing in its mother’s womb, so you cannot understand the activity of God, who does all things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Plant your seed in the morning and keep busy all afternoon, for you don’t know if profit will come from one activity or another—or maybe both.
speaker: Narrator

text: Light is sweet; how pleasant to see a new day dawning.
speaker: Narrator

text: When people live to be very old, let them rejoice in every day of life. But let them also remember there will be many dark days. Everything still to come is meaningless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Young people, it’s wonderful to be young! Enjoy every minute of it. Do everything you want to do; take it all in. But remember that you must give an account to God for everything you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: So refuse to worry, and keep your body healthy. But remember that youth, with a whole life before you, is meaningless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t let the excitement of youth cause you to forget your Creator. Honor him in your youth before you grow old and say, “Life is not pleasant anymore.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember him before the light of the sun, moon, and stars is dim to your old eyes, and rain clouds continually darken your sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember him before your legs—the guards of your house—start to tremble; and before your shoulders—the strong men—stoop. Remember him before your teeth—your few remaining servants—stop grinding; and before your eyes—the women looking through the windows—see dimly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember him before the door to life’s opportunities is closed and the sound of work fades. Now you rise at the first chirping of the birds, but then all their sounds will grow faint.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember him before you become fearful of falling and worry about danger in the streets; before your hair turns white like an almond tree in bloom, and you drag along without energy like a dying grasshopper, and the caperberry no longer inspires sexual desire. Remember him before you near the grave, your everlasting home, when the mourners will weep at your funeral.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, remember your Creator now while you are young, before the silver cord of life snaps and the golden bowl is broken. Don’t wait until the water jar is smashed at the spring and the pulley is broken at the well.
speaker: Narrator

text: For then the dust will return to the earth, and the spirit will return to God who gave it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Everything is meaningless,” says the Teacher, “completely meaningless.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep this in mind: The Teacher was considered wise, and he taught the people everything he knew. He listened carefully to many proverbs, studying and classifying them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Teacher sought to find just the right words to express truths clearly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of the wise are like cattle prods—painful but helpful. Their collected sayings are like a nail-studded stick with which a shepherd drives the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: But, my child, let me give you some further advice: Be careful, for writing books is endless, and much study wears you out.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s the whole story. Here now is my final conclusion: Fear God and obey his commands, for this is everyone’s duty.
speaker: Narrator

text: God will judge us for everything we do, including every secret thing, whether good or bad.
speaker: Narrator
